1.description: 1.1.1 Set 'Enforce password history' to '24 or more'
1.info: This policy setting determines the number of renewed, unique passwords that have to be associated with a user account before you can reuse an old password.
1.solution: Make sure 'Enforce password history' is set to a minimum of 24 passwords.

2.description: 1.1.3 Set 'Minimum password age' to '1 or more day(s)'
2.info: This policy setting determines the number of days that you must use a password before you can change it.
2.solution: Make sure minimum password age is set to a minimum of 1 day.

3.description: 1.1.4 Set 'Minimum password length' to '8 or more character(s)'
3.info: This policy setting determines the least number of characters that make up a password for a user account.
3.solution: Make sure 'Minimum password length' is set to a minimum of 8 characters.

4.description: 1.1.5 Set 'Password must meet complexity requirements' to 'Enabled'
4.info: This policy setting checks all new passwords to ensure that they meet basic requirements for strong passwords.
4.solution: Make sure 'Password must meet complexity requirements' is set to a minimum of 24 passwords.

5.description: 1.1.6 Set 'Store passwords using reversible encryption' to 'Disabled'
5.info: This policy setting determines whether the operating system stores passwords in a way that uses reversible  encryption, which provides support for application protocols that require knowledge of the user's password  for authentication purposes.
5.solution: Make sure 'Store passwords using reversible encryption' is disabled.

6.description: 1.2.1 Set 'Account lockout duration' to '120 or higher'
6.info: This policy setting determines the length of time that must pass before a locked account is unlocked and a user can try to log on again.
6.solution: Make sure 'Account lockout duration' is set to 120 minutes or more

7.description: 1.2.2 Set 'Account lockout threshold' to '3 or fewer but not 0 invalid logon attempt(s)'
7.info: This policy setting determines the number of failed logon attempts before a lock occurs.
7.solution: Make sure 'Account lockout threshold' is set to 3 or fewer but not 0 invalid attempts.

8.description: 1.2.3 Set 'Reset account lockout counter after' to '120 or greater'
8.info: This policy setting determines the length of time before the Account lockout threshold resets to zero.
8.solution: Make sure 'Reset account lockout counter after' is set to 120 minutes or greater

9.description: 2.2.1 Set 'Access Credential Manager as a trusted caller' to 'No One'
9.info: This security setting is used by Credential Manager during Backup and Restore.
9.solution: Make sure 'Access Credential Manager as a trusted caller' is set no one.

10.description: 2.2.2 Set 'Access this computer from the network' to 'Administrators, Authenticated Users'
10.info: This policy setting allows other users on the network to connect to the computer and is required by various  network protocols that include Server Message Block (SMB)-based protocols, NetBIOS, Common Internet File System (CIFS),  and Component Object Model Plus (COM+).
10.solution: Make sure 'Access this computer from the network' is set to administrators and usersllers.

11.description: 2.2.3 Set 'Act as part of the operating system' to 'No One'
11.info: This policy setting allows a process to assume the identity of any user and thus gain access to the resources that the user is authorized to access.
11.solution: Make sure no one can act as part of the operating system.

12.description: 2.2.4 Set 'Adjust memory quotas for a process' to 'Administrators, Local Service, Network Service'
12.info: This policy setting allows a user to adjust the maximum amount of memory that is available to a process.
12.solution: Make sure 'Adjust memory quotas for a process' is set to administrators, local service and network service.

13.description: 2.2.5 Set 'Allow log on locally' to 'Administrators, Users'
13.info: This policy setting determines which users can interactively log on to computers in your environment.
13.solution: Make sure 'Allow log on locally' is set to administrators and users.

14.description: 2.2.6 Set 'Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services' to 'Administrators, Remote Desktop Users'
14.info: This policy setting determines which users or groups have the right to log on as a Terminal Services client.
14.solution: Make sure 'Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services' is set to administrators and Remote Desktop Users.

15.description: 2.2.7 Set 'Back up files and directories' to 'Administrators'
15.info: This policy setting allows users to circumvent file and directory permissions to back up the system.
15.solution: Make sure 'Back up files and directories' is set to administrators.

16.description: 2.2.8 Set 'Change the system time' to 'LOCAL SERVICE, Administrators'
16.info: This policy setting determines which users and groups can change the time and date on the internal clock of the computers in your environment.
16.solution: Make sure 'Change the system time' is set to local service and administrators.

17.description: 2.2.9 Set 'Change the time zone' to 'LOCAL SERVICE, Administrators, Users'
17.info: This setting determines which users can change the time zone of the computer.
17.solution: Make sure 'Change the time zone' is set to local service, administrators, and users.

18.info: This policy setting allows users to change the size of the pagefile.
18.solution: Make sure 'Create a pagefile' is set to administrators.

19.description: 2.2.11 Set 'Create a token object' to 'No One'
19.info: This policy setting allows a process to create an access token, which may provide elevated rights to access sensitive data.
19.solution: Make sure no one has the user right 'Create a token object'

20.description: 2.2.12 Set 'Create global objects' to 'Administrators, SERVICE, LOCAL SERVICE, NETWORK SERVICE'
20.info: This policy setting determines whether users can create global objects that are available to all sessions.
20.solution: Make sure 'Create global objects' is set to administrators, service, local service and network service.
20.value_data: Administrators && Local Service && Network Service && Service

21.description: 2.2.13 Set 'Create permanent shared objects' to 'No One'
21.info: This user right is useful to kernel-mode components that extend the object namespace.
21.solution: Make sure 'Create permanent shared objects' is set to No One.

22.info: This policy setting determines which users can create symbolic links.
22.solution: Make sure 'Create symbolic links' is set to administrators.

23.info: This policy setting determines which user accounts will have the right to attach a debugger to any process or to the kernel.
23.solution: Make sure 'Debug programs' is set to administrators only.

24.description: 2.2.16 Set 'Deny access to this computer from the network' to include 'Guests, Local account'
24.info: This policy setting prohibits users from connecting to a computer from across the network.
24.solution: Make sure 'Deny access to this computer from the network' is set to guests and local account.

25.description: 2.2.17 Set 'Deny log on as a batch job' to 'Guests'
25.info: This policy setting determines which accounts will not be able to log on to the computer as a batch job.
25.solution: Make sure 'Deny log on as a batch job' is set to guests.

26.description: 2.2.18 Set 'Deny log on as a service' to include 'Guests'
26.info: This security setting determines which service accounts are prevented from registering a process as a service.
26.solution: Make sure 'Deny log on as service' is set to 'Guests'.

27.info: This security setting determines which users are prevented from logging on at the computer.
27.solution: Make sure 'Deny log on locally' is set to guest accounts only.

28.description: 2.2.20 Set 'Deny log on through Remote Desktop Services' to include 'Guests, Local account'
28.info: This policy setting determines whether users can log on as Terminal Services clients.
28.solution: Make sure 'Deny log on through Remote Desktop Services' to 'Guests, Local account'.

29.description: 2.2.21 Set 'Enable computer and user accounts to be trusted for delegation' to 'No One'
29.info: This policy setting allows users to change the Trusted for Delegation setting on a computer object in Active Directory.
29.solution: Make sure 'Enable computer and user accounts to be trusted for delegation' is set to no one.

30.description: 2.2.22 Set 'Force shutdown from a remote system' to 'Administrators'
30.info: This policy setting allows users to shut down Windows Vista-based computers from remote locations on the network.
30.solution: Make sure 'Force shutdown from a remote system' is set to administrators.

31.description: 2.2.23 Set 'Generate security audits' to 'LOCAL SERVICE, NETWORK SERVICE'
31.info: This policy setting determines which users or processes can generate audit records in the Security log.
31.solution: Make sure 'Generate security audits' is set to Local Service and Network Service.

32.description: 2.2.24 Set 'Impersonate a client after authentication' to 'Administrators, SERVICE, Local Service, Network Service'
32.info: The policy setting allows programs that run on behalf of a user to impersonate that user so that they can act on behalf of the user.
32.solution: Make sure 'Impersonate a client after authentication' is set to Administrators, SERVICE, Local Service and Network Service.
32.value_data: Administrators && Local Service && Network Service && Service

33.info: This policy setting determines whether users can increase the base priority class of a process.
33.solution: Make sure 'Increase scheduling priority' is set to Administrators.

34.description: 2.2.26 Set 'Load and unload device drivers' to 'Administrators'
34.info: This policy setting allows users to dynamically load a new device driver on a system.
34.solution: Make sure 'Load and unload device drivers' is set to Administrators.

35.description: 2.2.27 Set 'Lock pages in memory' to 'No One'
35.info: This policy setting allows a process to keep data in physical memory, which prevents the system from paging the data to virtual memory on disk.
35.solution: Make sure 'Lock pages in memory' is set to 'no one'.

36.description: 2.2.28 Set 'Manage auditing and security log' to 'Administrators'
36.info: This policy setting determines which users can change the auditing options for files and directories and clear the Security log.
36.solution: Make sure 'Manage auditing and security log' is set to Administrators.

37.description: 2.2.29 Set 'Modify an object label' to 'No one'
37.info: This privilege determines which user accounts can modify the integrity label of objects, such as files, registry keys, or processes owned by other users.
37.solution: Make sure 'Modify an object label' is set to no one.

38.info: This policy setting allows users to configure the system-wide environment variables that affect hardware configuration.
38.solution: Make sure 'Modify firmware environment values' is set to Administrators.

39.info: This policy setting allows users to manage the system's volume or disk configuration, which could allow a user to delete a volume and cause data loss as well as a denial-of-service condition.
39.solution: Make sure 'Perform volume maintenance tasks' is set to Administrators.

40.info: This policy setting determines which users can use tools to monitor the performance of non-system processes.
40.solution: Make sure 'Profile single process' is set to Administrators.

41.info: This policy setting allows users to use tools to view the performance of different system processes, which could be abused to allow attackers to determine a system's active processes and provide insight into the potential attack surface of the computer.
41.solution: Make sure 'Profile system performance' is set to Administrators and NT SERVICE\WdiServiceHost.

42.description: 2.2.34 Set 'Replace a process level token' to 'Local Service, Network Service'
42.info: This policy setting allows one process or service to start another service or process with a different security access token.
42.solution: Make sure 'Replace a process level token' is set to Local Service and Network Service.

43.info: This policy setting determines which users can bypass file, directory, registry, and other persistent object permissions when restoring backed up files and directories on computers that run Windows Vista in your environment.
43.solution: Make sure 'Restore files and directories' is set to Administrators.

44.description: 2.2.36 Set 'Shut down the system' to 'Administrators, Users'
44.info: This policy setting determines which users can shut down the operating system with the Shut Down command.
44.solution: Make sure 'Shut down the system' is set to Administrators.

45.description: 2.2.37 Set 'Take ownership of files or other objects' to 'Administrators'
45.info: This policy setting allows users to take ownership of files, folders, registry keys, processes, or threads.
45.solution: Make sure 'Take ownership of files or other objects' is set to Administrators.

46.info: This policy setting enables or disables the Administrator account during normal operation.
46.solution: Make sure 'Accounts: Administrator account status' is set to Disabled.

47.description: 2.3.1.2 Set 'Accounts: Block Microsoft accounts' to 'Users can't add or log on with Microsoft accounts'
47.info: This policy setting prevents users from adding new Microsoft accounts on this computer.
47.solution: Make sure 'Accounts: Block Microsoft accounts' is set to 'Users can't add or log on with Microsoft accounts'

48.info: This policy setting determines whether the Guest account is enabled or disabled.
48.solution: Make sure 'Accounts: Guest account status' is set to Disabled.

49.description: 2.3.1.4 Set 'Accounts: Limit local account use of blank passwords to console logon only' to 'Enabled'
49.info: This policy setting determines whether local accounts that are not password protected can be used to log on from locations other than the physical computer console.
49.solution: Make sure 'Accounts: Limit local account use of blank passwords to console logon only' is enabled.

50.info: This policy setting enables or disables the Administrator account during normal operation.
50.solution: Make sure 'Rename administrator account' is not set to Administrator or Admin (non standard).

51.info: This control recommends choosing a name for the built-in local guest account that is different from the default.
51.solution: Make sure 'Accounts: Rename guest account' is not set to guest.

52.description: 2.3.2.1 Set 'Audit: Force audit policy subcategory settings to override audit policy category settings' to 'Enabled'
52.info: This policy setting allows administrators to enable the more precise auditing capabilities present in Windows Vista.
52.solution: Make sure 'Audit: Force audit policy subcategory settings (Windows Vista or later) to override audit policy category settings' is set to enabled.

53.description: 2.3.2.2 Set 'Audit: Shut down system immediately if unable to log security audits' to 'Disabled'
53.info: This policy setting determines whether the system shuts down if it is unable to log Security events.
53.solution: Make sure 'Audit: Shut down system immediately if unable to log security audits' is set to disabled.

54.description: 2.3.4.1 Set 'Devices: Allowed to format and eject removable media' to 'Administrators and Interactive Users'
54.info: This policy setting determines who is allowed to format and eject removable media.
54.solution: Make sure 'Devices: Allowed to format and eject removable media' is set to administrators and interactive users.

55.description: 2.3.6.1 Set 'Domain member: Digitally encrypt or sign secure channel data (always)' to 'Enabled'
55.info: This policy setting determines whether all secure channel traffic that is initiated by the domain member must be signed or encrypted.
55.solution: Make sure 'Domain member: Digitally encrypt or sign secure channel data (always)' is set to enabled.

56.description: 2.3.6.2 Set 'Domain member: Digitally encrypt secure channel data (when possible)' to 'Enabled'
56.info: This policy setting determines whether a domain member should attempt to negotiate encryption for all secure channel traffic that it initiates.
56.solution: Make sure 'Domain member: Digitally encrypt secure channel data (when possible)' is enabled.

57.description: 2.3.6.3 Set 'Domain member: Digitally sign secure channel data (when possible)' to 'Enabled'
57.info: This policy setting determines whether a domain member should attempt to negotiate whether all secure channel traffic that it initiates must be digitally signed.
57.solution: Make sure 'Domain member: Digitally sign secure channel data (when possible)' is enabled.

58.description: 2.3.6.4 Set 'Domain member: Disable machine account password changes' to 'Disabled'
58.info: This policy setting determines whether a domain member can periodically change its computer account password.
58.solution: Make sure 'Domain member: Disable machine account password changes' is disabled.

59.description: 2.3.6.5 Set 'Domain member: Maximum machine account password age' to '30 or fewer days, but not 0'
59.info: This policy setting determines the maximum allowable age for a computer account password.
59.solution: Make sure 'Domain member: Maximum machine account password age' is set to a maximum of 30 days, but not 0. A value of 0 disables maximum password age.

60.description: 2.3.6.6 Set 'Domain member: Require strong (Windows 2000 or later) session key' to 'Enabled'
60.info: When this policy setting is enabled, a secure channel can only be established with domain controllers that are capable of encrypting secure channel data with a strong (128-bit) session key.
60.solution: Make sure 'Domain member: Require strong (Windows 2000 or later) session key' is enabled.

61.description: 2.3.7.1 Set 'Interactive logon: Do not display last user name' to 'Enabled'
61.info: This policy setting determines whether the account name of the last user to log on to the client computers in your organization will be displayed in each computer's respective Windows logon screen.
61.solution: Make sure 'Interactive logon: Do not display last user name' is enabled.

62.description: 2.3.7.2 Set 'Interactive logon: Do not require CTRL+ALT+DEL' to 'Disabled'
62.info: This policy setting determines whether users must press CTRL+ALT+DEL before they log on.
62.solution: Make sure 'Interactive logon: Do not require CTRL+ALT+DEL' is disabled.

63.description: 2.3.7.4 Set 'Interactive logon: Machine inactivity limit' to '900 or fewer seconds' but not 0
63.info: Windows notices inactivity of a logon session, and if the amount of inactive time exceeds the inactivity limit, then the screen saver will run, locking the session.
63.solution: Make sure 'Interactive logon: Machine inactivity limit' to '900 or fewer seconds' is set to a maximum of 900 seconds (15 minutes), but not 0.

64.description: 2.3.7.7 Set 'Interactive logon: Number of previous logons to cache (in case domain controller is not available)' to '2 or fewer logon(s)'
64.info: This policy setting determines whether a user can log on to a Windows domain using cached account information.
64.solution: Make sure 'Interactive logon: Number of previous logons to cache (in case domain controller is not available)' is set to 2 or fewer logons.

65.description: 2.3.7.8 Set 'Interactive logon: Prompt user to change password before expiration' to '14 days or greater'
65.info: This policy setting determines how far in advance users are warned that their password will expire.
65.solution: Make sure 'Interactive logon: Prompt user to change password before expiration' is set to greater than 14 days.

66.description: 2.3.7.9 Set 'Interactive logon: Smart card removal behavior' to 'Lock Workstation' or higher
66.info: This policy setting determines what happens when the smart card for a logged-on user is removed from the smart card reader. The recommended state for this setting is: Lock Workstation. Configuring this setting to 'Force Logoff' or 'Disconnect if a Remote Desktop Services session' also conforms with the benchmark.
66.solution: Make sure 'Interactive logon: Smart card removal behavior' is set to lock the workstation.

67.description: 2.3.8.1 Set 'Microsoft network client: Digitally sign communications (always)' to 'Enabled'
67.info: This policy setting determines whether packet signing is required by the SMB client component.
67.solution: Make sure 'Microsoft network client: Digitally sign communications (always)' is set to enabled.

68.description: 2.3.8.2 Set 'Microsoft network client: Digitally sign communications (if server agrees)' to 'Enabled'
68.info: This policy setting determines whether the SMB client will attempt to negotiate SMB packet signing.
68.solution: Make sure 'Microsoft network client: Digitally sign communications (if server agrees)' is set to enabled.

69.description: 2.3.8.3 Set 'Microsoft network client: Send unencrypted password to third-party SMB servers' to 'Disabled'
69.info: Disable this policy setting to prevent the SMB redirector from sending plaintext passwords during authentication to third-party SMB servers that do not support password encryption.
69.solution: Make sure 'Microsoft network client: Send unencrypted password to third-party SMB servers' is set to disabled.

70.description: 2.3.9.1 Set 'Microsoft network server: Amount of idle time required before suspending session' to '15 or fewer minute(s)' but not 0
70.info: This policy setting allows you to specify the amount of continuous idle time that must pass in an SMB session before the session is suspended because of inactivity.
70.solution: Make sure 'Microsoft network server: Amount of idle time required before suspending session' is set to a maximum of 15 minutes, but not 0.

71.description: 2.3.9.2 Set 'Microsoft network server: Digitally sign communications (always)' to 'Enabled'
71.info: This policy setting determines if the server side SMB service is required to perform SMB packet signing.
71.solution: Make sure 'Microsoft network server: Digitally sign communications (always)' is set to enabled.

72.description: 2.3.9.3 Set 'Microsoft network server: Digitally sign communications (if client agrees)' to 'Enabled'
72.info: This policy setting determines if the server side SMB service is able to sign SMB packets if it is requested to do so by a client that attempts to establish a connection.
72.solution: Make sure 'Microsoft network server: Digitally sign communications (if client agrees)' is enabled.

73.description: 2.3.9.4 Set 'Microsoft network server: Disconnect clients when logon hours expire' to 'Enabled'
73.info: This policy setting determines whether to disconnect users who are connected to the local computer outside their user account's valid logon hours.
73.solution: Make sure 'Microsoft network server: Disconnect clients when logon hours expire' is enabled.

74.description: 2.3.9.5 Set 'Microsoft network server: Server SPN target name validation level' to 'Accept if provided by client'
74.solution: Make sure 'Microsoft network server: Server SPN target name validation level' is set to 'Accept if provided by client' on the service principal name (SPN) that is provided by the client computer when it establishes a session using the server message block (SMB) protocol.

75.description: 2.3.10.1 Set 'Network access: Allow anonymous SID/Name translation' to 'Disabled'
75.info: This policy setting determines whether an anonymous user can request security identifier (SID) attributes for another user, or use a SID to obtain its corresponding user name.
75.solution: Make sure 'Network access: Allow anonymous SID/Name translation' is disabled.

76.description: 2.3.10.2 Set 'Network access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts' to 'Enabled'
76.info: This policy setting controls the ability of anonymous users to enumerate the accounts in the Security Accounts Manager.
76.solution: Make sure 'Network access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts' is enabled.

77.description: 2.3.10.3 Set 'Network access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts and shares' to 'Enabled'
77.info: This policy setting controls the ability of anonymous users to enumerate SAM accounts as well as shares.
77.solution: Make sure 'Network access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts and shares' is enabled.

78.description: 2.3.10.4 Set 'Network Access: Do not allow storage of passwords and credentials for network authentication' to 'Enabled'
78.info: This policy setting determines whether the Stored User Names and Passwords feature may save passwords or credentials for later use when it gains domain authentication.
78.solution: Make sure 'Network Access: Do not allow storage of passwords and credentials for network authentication' is enabled

79.description: 2.3.10.5 Set 'Network access: Let Everyone permissions apply to anonymous users' to 'Disabled'
79.info: This policy setting determines what additional permissions are assigned for anonymous connections to the computer.

80.description: 2.3.10.6 Set 'Network access: Named Pipes that can be access anonymously' to 'None'
80.info: This policy setting determines which communication sessions, or pipes, will have attributes and permissions that allow anonymous access.
80.solution: Make sure 'Named Pipes' that can be accessed anonymously is set to 'None'.

81.description: 2.3.10.7 Set 'Network access: Remotely accessible registry paths' to the following list
81.info: This policy setting determines which registry paths and sub-paths will be accessible when an application or process references the WinReg key.
81.solution: Make sure Remotely accessible registry paths are set to  'System\CurrentControlSet\Control\ProductOptions',  'System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Server Applications',  'Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion'.

82.description: 2.3.10.8 Set 'Network access: Remotely accessible registry paths and sub-paths' to the following list
82.info: This policy setting determines which registry paths and sub-paths will be accessible when an application or process references the WinReg key to determine access permissions.
82.solution: Make sure Remotely accessible registry paths are set to  'System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Print\Printers',  'System\CurrentControlSet\Services\Eventlog',  'Software\Microsoft\OLAP Server',  'Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Print',  'Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows',  'System\CurrentControlSet\Control\ContentIndex',  'System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server',  'System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server\UserConfig',  'System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server\DefaultUserConfiguration',  'Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Perflib',  'System\CurrentControlSet\Services\SysmonLog'.
82.value_data: Software\Microsoft\OLAP Server && Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Perflib && Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Print && Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows && System\CurrentControlSet\Control\ContentIndex && System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Print\Printers && System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server && System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server\DefaultUserConfiguration && System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server\UserConfig && System\CurrentControlSet\Services\Eventlog && System\CurrentControlSet\Services\Sysmonlog

83.description: 2.3.10.9 Set 'Network access: Restrict anonymous access to Named Pipes and Shares' to 'Enabled'
83.info: When enabled, this policy setting restricts anonymous access to only those shares and pipes that are named in the Named pipes and Shares.

84.description: 2.3.10.10 Configure Network access: Shares that can be accessed anonymously to 'None'
84.info: This policy setting determines which network shares can be accessed by anonymous users.
84.solution: Make sure NullSessionShares is set to none.

85.description: 2.3.10.11 Set 'Network access: Sharing and security model for local accounts' to 'Classic - local users authenticate as themselves'
85.info: This policy setting determines how network logons that use local accounts are authenticated.
85.solution: Make sure 'Network access: Sharing and security model for local accounts' is set to classic.

86.description: 2.3.11.1 Set 'Network security: Allow Local System to use computer identity for NTLM' to 'Enabled'
86.info: This policy setting causes Local System services that use Negotiate to use the computer identity when NTLM authentication is selected by the negotiation.
86.solution: Make sure 'Allow Local System to use computer identity for NTLM' is configured to 'Enabled'

87.description: 2.3.11.2 Set 'Network security: Allow LocalSystem NULL session fallback' to 'Disabled'
87.info: This control determines if a service is allowed to establish a NULL session connection.
87.solution: Make sure 'Allow LocalSystem NULL session fallback' is configured to 'Disabled'

88.description: 2.3.11.3 Set 'Network Security: Allow PKU2U authentication requeststo this computer to use online identities' to 'Disabled'
88.info: The PKU2U protocol is a peer-to-peer authentication protocol. In most managed networks authentication should be managed centrally.
88.solution: Make sure 'Network Security: Allow PKU2U authentication requests to this computer to use online identities' is set to your organization's security policy.

89.description: 2.3.11.4 Set 'Network Security: Configure encryption types allowed for Kerberos' to 'RC4_HMAC_MD5/AES128_HMAC_SHA1/AES256_HMAC_SHA1/Future'
89.info: This policy setting allows you to set the encryption types that Kerberos is allowed to use.
89.solution: Set 'Network Security: Configure encryption types allowed for Kerberos' to 'RC4_HMAC_MD5 / AES128_HMAC_SHA1 / AES256_HMAC_SHA1 / Future encryption types'

90.description: 2.3.11.5 Set 'Network security: Do not store LAN Manager hash value on next password change' to 'Enabled'
90.info: This policy setting determines whether the LAN Manager (LM) hash value for the new password is stored when the password is changed.
90.solution: Make sure 'Network security: Do not store LAN Manager hash value on next password change' is enabled.

91.description: 2.3.11.6 Configure 'Network security: Force logoff when logon hours expire' to 'Enabled'
91.info: This policy setting determines whether to disconnect users who are connected to the local computer outside their user account's valid logon hours.
91.solution: Make sure 'Network security: Force logoff when logon hours expire' is set to enabled.

92.description: 2.3.11.7 Set 'Network security: LAN Manager authentication level' to 'Send NTLMv2 response only. Refuse LM & NTLM'
92.info: LAN Manager (LM) is a family of early Microsoft client/server software that allows users to link personal computers together on a single network.
92.solution: Make sure 'Network security: LAN Manager authentication level' is set to send NTLMv2 response only and refuse LM and NTLM.

93.description: 2.3.11.8 Set 'Network security: LDAP client signing requirements' to 'Negotiate signing or higher
93.info: This policy setting determines the level of data signing that is requested on behalf of clients that issue LDAP BIND requests.
93.solution: Make sure 'Network security: LDAP client signing requirements' is set to negotiate signing or higher.

94.description: 2.3.11.9 Set 'Minimum session security for NTLM SSP based clients' to 'Require NTLMv2 session security,Require 128-bit encryption'
94.info: This policy setting determines which behaviors are allowed for applications using the NTLM Security Support Provider.
94.solution: Make sure 'Network security: Minimum session security for NTLM SSP based (including secure RPC) clients' is set to require NTLMv2 session security and 128-bit encryption.

95.description: 2.3.11.10 Set 'Minimum session security for NTLM SSP based servers' to 'Require NTLMv2 session security,Require 128-bit encryption'
95.info: This policy setting determines which behaviors are allowed for applications using the NTLM Security Support Provider.
95.solution: Make sure 'Network security: Minimum session security for NTLM SSP based (including secure RPC) servers' is set to require NTLMv2 session security and 128-bit encryption.

96.description: 2.3.12.1 Set 'Recovery console: Allow automatic administrative logon' to 'Disabled'
96.info: The recovery console is a command-line environment that is used to recover from system problems.
96.solution: Make sure 'Recovery console: Allow automatic administrative logon' is disabled.

97.description: 2.3.12.2 Set 'Recovery console: Allow floppy copy and access to all drives and all folders' to 'Disabled'
97.info: This policy setting makes the Recovery Console SET command available which allows you to set the following recovery
97.console environment variables: - AllowWildCards. Enables wildcard support for some commands (such as the DEL command).  - AllowAllPaths. Allows access to all files and folders on the computer. - AllowRemovableMedia. Allows files to be  copied to removable media, such as a floppy disk.
97.solution: Make sure 'Recovery console: Allow floppy copy and access to all drives and all folders' is disabled.

98.description: 2.3.15.1 Set 'System objects: Require case insensitivity for non-Windows subsystems' to 'Enabled'
98.info: This policy setting determines whether case insensitivity is enforced for all subsystems.
98.solution: Make sure 'System objects: Require case insensitivity for non-Windows subsystems' is enabled.

99.description: 2.3.15.2 Set 'System objects: Strengthen default permissions of internal system objects (e.g. Symbolic Links)' to 'Enabled'
99.info: This policy setting determines the strength of the default discretionary access control list (DACL) for objects.
99.solution: Make sure 'System objects: Strengthen default permissions of internal system objects' is enabled.

100.description: 2.3.17.1 Set 'User Account Control: Admin Approval Mode for the Built-in Administrator account' to 'Enabled'
100.info: This policy setting controls the behavior of Admin Approval Mode for the built-in Administrator account.
100.solution: Make sure 'User Account Control: Admin Approval Mode for the Built-in Administrator account' is enabled.

101.description: 2.3.17.2 Set 'User Account Control: Allow UIAccess applications to prompt for elevation without using the secure desktop' to 'Disabled'
101.info: This policy setting controls whether User Interface Accessibility (UIAccess or UIA) programs can automatically disable the secure desktop for elevation prompts used by a standard user.
101.solution: Make sure 'User Account Control: Allow UIAccess applications to prompt for elevation without using the secure desktop' is disabled.

102.description: 2.3.17.3 Set 'User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for administrators in Admin Approval Mode' to 'Prompt for consent'
102.info: This policy setting controls the behavior of the elevation prompt for administrators.
102.solution: Make sure 'User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for administrators in Admin Approval Mode' is set to 'Prompt for consent on the secure desktop'

103.description: 2.3.17.4 Set 'User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users' to 'Automatically deny elevation requests'
103.info: This policy setting controls the behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users
103.solution: Make sure 'Behavior of the Elevation Prompt for Standard Users' is set to Automatically deny elevation requests.

104.description: 2.3.17.5 Set 'User Account Control: Detect application installations and prompt for elevation' to 'Enabled'
104.info: This policy setting controls the behavior of application installation detection for the computer.
104.solution: Make sure 'User Account Control: Detect application installations and prompt for elevation' is enabled.

105.description: 2.3.17.6 Set 'User Account Control: Only elevate UIAccess applications that are installed in secure locations' to 'Enabled'
105.info: This policy setting controls whether applications that request to run with a User Interface Accessibility (UIAccess) integritylevel must reside in a secure location in the file system.
105.solution: Make sure 'Only Elevate UIAccess applications that are Installed in Secure Locations' is Enabled.

106.description: 2.3.17.7 Set 'User Account Control: Run all administrators in Admin Approval Mode' to 'Enabled'
106.info: This policy setting controls the behavior of all User Account Control (UAC) policy settings for the computer.
106.solution: Make sure 'User Account Control: Run all administrators in Admin Approval Mode' is enabled.

107.description: 2.3.17.8 Set 'User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation' to 'Enabled'
107.info: This policy setting controls whether the elevation request prompt is displayed on the interactive user's desktop or the secure desktop.
107.solution: Make sure 'User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation' is enabled.

108.description: 2.3.17.9 Set 'User Account Control: Virtualize file and registry write failures to per-user locations' to 'Enabled'
108.info: This policy setting controls whether application write failures are redirected to defined registry and file system locations.
108.solution: Make sure 'User Account Control: Virtualize file and registry write failures to per-user locations' is enabled.

109.description: 9.1.1 Set 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Firewall state' to 'On (recommended)'
109.info: Select On to have Windows Firewall with Advanced Security use the settings for this profile to filter network traffic.
109.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Firewall state' is set to On.

110.description: 9.1.2 Set 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Inbound connections' to 'Block (default)'
110.info: This setting determines the behavior for inbound connections that do not match an inbound firewall rule.
110.solution: Make sure 'Inbound connections' is set to the default setting Enabled:Block.

111.description: 9.1.3 Set 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Outbound connections' to 'Allow (default)'
111.info: This setting determines the behavior for outbound connections that do not match an outbound firewall rule.
111.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Outbound connections' is set to the default value of allow.

112.description: 9.1.4 Set 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Settings: Display a notification' to 'No'
112.info: This setting allows Windows Firewall with Advanced Security to display notifications to the user when a program is blocked.
112.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Display a notification' is set to 'No'.

113.description: 9.1.5 Set 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Settings: Allow unicast response' to 'No'
113.info: This setting controls whether this computer receives unicast responses to its outgoing multicast or broadcast messages.
113.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Allow unicast response' is set to no.

114.description: 9.1.6 Set 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Settings: Apply local firewall rules' to 'Yes (default)'
114.info: This setting controls whether local administrators are allowed to create local firewall rules that apply together with firewall rules configured by Group Policy.
114.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Apply local firewall rules' is set to yes.

115.description: 9.1.7 Set 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Settings: Apply local connection security rules' to 'Yes (default)'
115.info: This setting controls whether local administrators are allowed to create connection security rules that apply together with connection security rules configured by Group Policy.
115.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Settings: Apply local connection security rules' is set to Yes.

116.description: 9.1.8 Set 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Logging: Name' to '%SYSTEMROOT%\System32\logfiles\firewall\domainfw.log'
116.info: Use this option to specify the path and name of the file in which Windows Firewall will write its log information.
116.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Logging: Name' is set to '%SYSTEMROOT%\System32\logfiles\firewall\domainfw.log'

117.description: 9.1.9 Set 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Logging: Size limit (KB)' to '16,384 KB or greater'
117.info: Use this option to specify the size limit of the file in which Windows Firewall will write its log information.
117.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Logging: Size limit (KB)' is set to '16,384 KB or greater'

118.description: 9.1.10 Set 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Logging: Log dropped packets' to 'Yes'
118.info: Use this option to log when Windows Firewall with Advanced Security discards an inbound packet for any reason.
118.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Logging: Log dropped packets' is set to the default value of Yes.

119.description: 9.1.11 Set 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Logging: Log successful connections' to 'Yes'
119.info: Use this option to log when Windows Firewall with Advanced Security allows an inbound connection.
119.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Logging: Log successful connections' is set to 'Yes'.

120.description: 9.2.1 Set 'Windows Firewall: Private: Firewall state' to 'On (recommended)'
120.info: Select On to have Windows Firewall with Advanced Security use the settings for this profile to filter network traffic.
120.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Private: Firewall state' is set to on.

121.description: 9.2.2 Set 'Windows Firewall: Private: Inbound connections' to 'Block (default)'
121.info: This setting determines the behavior for inbound connections that do not match an inbound firewall rule.
121.solution: Make sure 'Inbound connections' is set to the default Enabled:Block.

122.description: 9.2.3 Set 'Windows Firewall: Private: Outbound connections' to 'Allow (default)'
122.info: This setting determines the behavior for outbound connections that do not match an outbound firewall rule.
122.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Private: Outbound connections' is set to the default setting Allow.

123.description: 9.2.4 Set 'Windows Firewall: Private: Display a notification' to 'No'
123.info: This setting allows Windows Firewall with Advanced Security to display notifications to the user when a program is blocked.
123.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Private: Display a notification' is set to No.

124.description: 9.2.5 Set 'Windows Firewall: Private: Allow unicast response' to 'No'
124.info: This setting controls whether this computer receives unicast responses to its outgoing multicast or broadcast messages.
124.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Private: Allow unicast response' is set to no.

125.description: 9.2.6 Set 'Windows Firewall: Private: Apply local firewall rules' to 'Yes (default)'
125.info: This setting controls whether local administrators are allowed to create local firewall rules that apply together with firewall rules configured by Group Policy.
125.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Private: Apply local firewall rules' is set to yes (default setting).

126.description: 9.2.7 Set 'Windows Firewall: Private: Apply local connection security rules' to 'Yes (default)'
126.info: This setting controls whether local administrators are allowed to create connection security rules that apply together with connection security rules configured by Group Policy.
126.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Private: Apply local connection security rules' is set to yes.

127.description: 9.2.8 Set 'Windows Firewall: Private: Logging: Name' to '%SYSTEMROOT%\System32\logfiles\firewall\privatefw.log'
127.info: Use this option to specify the path and name of the file in which Windows Firewall will write its log information.
127.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Private: Logging: Name' is set to '%SYSTEMROOT%\System32\logfiles\firewall\privatefw.log'

128.description: 9.2.9 Set 'Windows Firewall: Private: Logging: Size limit (KB)' to '16,384 KB or greater'
128.info: Use this option to specify the size limit of the file in which Windows Firewall will write its log information.
128.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Private: Logging: Size limit (KB)' is set to '16,384 KB or greater'

129.description: 9.2.10 Set 'Windows Firewall: Private: Logging: Log dropped packets' to 'Yes'
129.info: Use this option to log when Windows Firewall with Advanced Security discards an inbound packet for any reason.
129.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Private: Logging: Log dropped packets' is set to Yes.

130.description: 9.2.11 Set 'Windows Firewall: Private: Logging: Log successful connections' to 'Yes'
130.info: Use this option to log when Windows Firewall with Advanced Security allows an inbound connection.
130.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Private: Logging: Log successful connections' is set to Yes.

131.description: 9.3.1 Set 'Windows Firewall: Public: Firewall state' to 'On (recommended)'
131.info: Select On to have Windows Firewall with Advanced Security use the settings for this profile to filter network traffic.
131.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Public: Firewall state' is set to On.

132.description: 9.3.2 Set 'Windows Firewall: Public: Inbound connections' to 'Block (default)'
132.info: This setting determines the behavior for inbound connections that do not match an inbound firewall rule.
132.solution: Make sure 'Inbound connections' is set to the default Enabled:Block.

133.description: 9.3.3 Set 'Windows Firewall: Public: Outbound connections' to 'Allow (default)'
133.info: This setting determines the behavior for outbound connections that do not match an outbound firewall rule.
133.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Public: Outbound connections' is set to the default setting allow.

134.description: 9.3.4 Set 'Windows Firewall: Public: Display a notification' to 'Yes'
134.info: This setting allows Windows Firewall with Advanced Security to display notifications to the user when a program is blocked.
134.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Public: Display a notification' is set to Yes.

135.description: 9.3.5 Set 'Windows Firewall: Public: Allow unicast response' to 'No'
135.info: This setting controls whether this computer receives unicast responses to its outgoing multicast or broadcast messages.
135.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Public: Allow unicast response' is set to no.

136.description: 9.3.6 Set 'Windows Firewall: Public: Apply local firewall rules' to 'No'
136.info: This setting controls whether local administrators are allowed to create local firewall rules that apply together with firewall rules configured by Group Policy.
136.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Public: Apply local firewall rules' is set to No.

137.description: 9.3.7 Set 'Windows Firewall: Public: Apply local connection security rules' to 'No'
137.info: This setting controls whether local administrators are allowed to create connection security rules that apply together with connection security rules configured by Group Policy.
137.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Domain: Apply local connection security rules' is set to no.

138.description: 9.3.8 Set 'Windows Firewall: Public: Logging: Name' to '%SYSTEMROOT%\System32\logfiles\firewall\publicfw.log'
138.info: Use this option to specify the path and name of the file in which Windows Firewall will write its log information.
138.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Public: Logging: Name' is set to '%SYSTEMROOT%\System32\logfiles\firewall\publicfw.log'

139.description: 9.3.9 Set 'Windows Firewall: Public: Logging: Size limit (KB)' to '16,384 KB or greater'
139.info: Use this option to specify the size limit of the file in which Windows Firewall will write its log information.
139.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Public: Logging: Size limit (KB)' is set to '16,384 KB or greater'

140.description: 9.3.10 Set 'Windows Firewall: Public: Logging: Log dropped packets' to 'Yes'
140.info: Use this option to log when Windows Firewall with Advanced Security discards an inbound packet for any reason.
140.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Public: Logging: Log dropped packets' is set to Yes.

141.description: 9.3.11 Set 'Windows Firewall: Public: Logging: Log successful connections' to 'Yes'
141.info: Use this option to log when Windows Firewall with Advanced Security allows an inbound connection.
141.solution: Make sure 'Windows Firewall: Public: Logging: Log successful connections' is set to 'Yes'.

142.description: 17.1.1 Set 'Audit Credential Validation' to 'Success and Failure'
142.info: This subcategory reports the results of validation tests on credentials submitted for a user account logon request.
142.solution: Make sure the audit policy 'Account Logon: Credential Validation' is set to success and failure.

143.description: 17.2.1 Set 'Audit Application Group Management' to 'Success and Failure'
143.info: This policy setting allows you to audit events generated by changes to application groups such as  'Application group is created, changed, or deleted.' and 'Member is added or removed from an application group.'
143.solution: Make sure 'Audit Application Group Management' is set to 'Success and Failure'.

144.description: 17.2.2 Set 'Audit Computer Account Management' to 'Success and Failure'
144.info: This subcategory reports each event of computer account management.
144.solution: Make sure 'Audit Computer Account Management' is set to success and failure.

145.description: 17.2.3 Set 'Audit Other Account Management Events' to 'Success and Failure'
145.info: This subcategory reports other account management events.
145.solution: Make sure 'Account Management: Other Account Management Events' is set to success and failure.

146.description: 17.2.4 Set 'Audit Security Group Management' to 'Success and Failure'
146.info: This subcategory reports each event of security group management, such as when a security group is created, changed, or deleted or when a member is added to or removed from a security group.
146.solution: Make sure 'Account Management: Security Group Management is set to success and failure.

147.description: 17.2.5 Set 'Audit User Account Management' to 'Success and Failure'
147.info: This subcategory reports each event of user account management, such as when a user account is created, changed, or deleted; a user account is renamed, disabled, or enabled; or a password is set or changed.
147.solution: Make sure 'Account Management: User Account Management' is set to success and failure.

148.info: This policy setting allows you to audit when plug and play detects an external device.
148.solution: Make sure 'Audit PNP Activity' is enabled.

149.info: This subcategory reports the creation of a process and the name of the program or user that created it.
149.solution: Make sure 'Detailed Tracking: Process Creation' is set to success.

150.info: This subcategory reports when a user's account is locked out as a result of too many failed logon attempts.
150.solution: Make sure 'Logon-Logoff: Account Lockout' is set to 'Success'.

151.info: This policy allows you to audit the group membership information in the user's logon token.
151.solution: Make sure 'Audit Group Membership' is set to Success'

152.info: This subcategory reports when a user logs off from the system.
152.solution: Make sure 'Logon-Logoff: Logoff' is set to 'Success

153.info: This subcategory reports when a user attempts to log on to the system.
153.solution: Make sure 'Logon-Logoff: Logon' is set to success and failure

154.description: 17.5.5 Set 'Audit Other Logon/Logoff Events' to 'Success and Failure'
154.info: This subcategory reports other logon/logoff-related events.
154.solution: Make sure 'Audit Other Logon/Logoff Events' is set to Success and Failure.

155.info: This subcategory reports when a special logon is used.
155.solution: Make sure 'Logon-Logoff: Special Logon' is set to Success (minimum).

156.description: 17.6.1 Set 'Audit Removable Storage' to 'Success and Failure'
156.info: This policy setting allows you to audit user attempts to access file system objects on a removable storage device.
156.solution: Make sure 'Audit Removable Storage' is set to success and failure.

157.description: 17.7.1 Set 'Audit Audit Policy Change' to 'Success and Failure'
157.info: This subcategory reports changes in audit policy including SACL changes.
157.solution: Make sure 'Policy Change: Audit Policy Change' is set to success and failure.

158.info: This subcategory reports changes in authentication policy.
158.solution: Make sure 'Policy Change: Authentication Policy Change' is set to Success (minimum).

159.description: 17.8.1 Set 'Audit Sensitive Privilege Use' to 'Success and Failure'
159.info: This subcategory reports when a user account or service uses a sensitive privilege.
159.solution: Make sure 'Privilege Use: Sensitive Privilege Use' is set to success and failure.

160.description: 17.9.1 Set 'Audit IPsec Driver' to 'Success and Failure'
160.info: This subcategory reports on the activities of the Internet Protocol security (IPsec) driver.
160.solution: Make sure 'System: IPsec Driver' is set to success and failure.

161.description: 17.9.2 Set 'Audit Other System Events' to 'Success and Failure'
161.info: This subcategory reports on other system events.
161.solution: Make sure 'System: Other System Events' is set to 'Success and Failure'.

162.info: This subcategory reports changes in security state of the system, such as when the security subsystem starts and stops.
162.solution: Make sure 'System: Security State Change' is set to success.

163.description: 17.9.4 Set 'Audit Security System Extension' to 'Success and Failure'
163.info: This subcategory reports the loading of extension code such as authentication packages by the security subsystem.
163.solution: Make sure 'System: Security System Extension' is set to success and failure.

164.description: 17.9.5 Set 'Audit System Integrity' to 'Success and Failure'
164.info: This subcategory reports on violations of integrity of the security subsystem.
164.solution: Make sure 'System: System Integrity' is set to success and failure.

165.description: 18.1.1.1 Set 'Prevent enabling lock screen camera' to 'Enabled'
165.info: Disables the lock screen camera toggle switch in PC Settings and prevents a camera from being invoked on the lock screen.
165.solution: Make sure 'Prevent enabling lock screen camera' is set to 'Enabled'.

166.description: 18.1.1.2 Set 'Prevent enabling lock screen slide show' to 'Enabled'
166.info: Disables the lock screen slide show settings in PC Settings and prevents a slide show from playing on the lock screen.
166.solution: Make sure 'Prevent enabling lock screen slide show' is set to 'Enabled'.

167.info: This policy enables the automatic learning component of input personalization that includes speech, inking, and typing.
167.solution: Make sure 'Allow Input Personalization' is set to 'Disabled'

168.description: 18.3.1 Set 'MSS: (AutoAdminLogon) Enable Automatic Logon (not recommended)' to 'Disabled'
168.info: This setting is separate from the Welcome screen feature in Windows XP and Windows Vista.

169.description: 18.3.2 Set 'MSS: IPv6 source routing protection level' to 'Highest protection, source routing is completely disabled'
169.info: IPv6 source routing is a mechanism that allows the sender to determine the IP route that a datagram should follow through the network.
169.solution: Make sure DisableIPSourceRouting is set to a value of Highest protection, source routing is completely disabled'

170.description: 18.3.3 Set 'MSS: IPv4 source routing protection level' to 'Highest protection, source routing is completely disabled'
170.info: IPv4 source routing is a mechanism that allows the sender to determine the IP route that a datagram should take through the network.
170.solution: Make sure DisableIPSourceRouting is set to a value of Highest protection, source routing is completely disabled.

171.description: 18.3.5 Set 'MSS: (EnableICMPRedirect) Allow ICMP redirects to override OSPF generated routes' to 'Disabled'
171.info: Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirects cause the IPv4 stack to plumb host routes. These routes override the Open Shortest Path First (OSPF) generated routes.

172.description: 18.3.7 Set 'MSS: (NoNameReleaseOnDemand) Allow the computer to ignore NetBIOS name release requests except from WINS servers' to 'Enabled'
172.info: NetBIOS over TCP/IP is a network protocol that among other things provides a way to easily resolve NetBIOS names that are registered on Windows-based systems to the IP addresses that are configured on those systems. This setting determines whether the computer releases its NetBIOS name when it receives a name-release request.

173.description: 18.3.9 Set 'MSS: (SafeDllSearchMode) Enable Safe DLL search mode (recommended)' to 'Enabled'
173.info: SafeDllSearchMode searches the folders that are specified in the system path and then searches the current working folder.
173.solution: Make sure SafeDllSearchMode is set to enabled.

174.description: 18.3.10 Set 'MSS: The time in seconds before the screen saver grace period expires' to '5 or fewer seconds'
174.info: The time in seconds before the screen saver grace period expires 5 or fewer seconds in the SCE.
174.solution: Make sure ScreenSaverGracePeriod is set to 5 or fewer seconds.

175.description: 18.3.13 Set 'MSS: Percentage threshold for the security event log at which the system will generate a warning' to '0.9 or less'
175.info: This setting can generate a security audit in the Security event log when the log reaches a user-defined threshold.
175.solution: Make sure WarningLevel is set to 90 percent.

176.description: 18.4.10.2 Set 'Prohibit installation and configuration of Network Bridge on your DNS domain network' to 'Enabled'
176.info: You can use this procedure to enable or disable the user's ability to install and configure a network bridge.
176.solution: Make sure 'Prohibit installation and configuration of Network Bridge on your DNS domain network' is set to 'Enabled'.

177.description: 18.4.10.3 Set 'Require domain users to elevate when setting a network's location' to 'Enabled'
177.info: This policy setting determines whether to require domain users to elevate when setting a network's location.
177.solution: Make sure 'Require domain users to elevate when setting a network's location' is set to 'Enabled'

178.description: 18.4.13.1 Set 'Hardened UNC Paths' to Enabled, with Require Mutual Auth, for all NETLOGON shares (RequireMutualAuthentication)
178.info: This policy setting configures secure access to UNC paths.
178.solution: Make sure 'Hardened UNC Paths' are set to 'Enabled', with 'Require Mutual Authentication' and 'Require Integrity' set for all NETLOGON and SYSVOL shares.

179.description: 18.4.13.1 Set 'Hardened UNC Paths' to Enabled, with Require Integrity, for all NETLOGON shares (RequireIntegrity)
179.info: This policy setting configures secure access to UNC paths.
179.solution: Make sure 'Hardened UNC Paths' are set to 'Enabled', with 'Require Mutual Authentication' and 'Require Integrity' set for all NETLOGON and SYSVOL shares.

180.description: 18.4.13.1 Set 'Hardened UNC Paths' to Enabled, with Require Mutual Auth, for all SYSVOL shares (RequireMutualAuthentication)
180.info: This policy setting configures secure access to UNC paths.
180.solution: Make sure 'Hardened UNC Paths' are set to 'Enabled', with 'Require Mutual Authentication' and 'Require Integrity' set for all NETLOGON and SYSVOL shares.

181.description: 18.4.13.1 Set 'Hardened UNC Paths' to Enabled, with Require Integrity, for all SYSVOL shares (RequireIntegrity)
181.info: This policy setting configures secure access to UNC paths.
181.solution: Make sure 'Hardened UNC Paths' are set to 'Enabled', with 'Require Mutual Authentication' and 'Require Integrity' set for all NETLOGON and SYSVOL shares.

182.description: 18.4.20.1 Set 'Prohibit connection to non-domain networks when connected to domain authenticated network' to 'Enabled'
182.info: This policy setting prevents computers from connecting to both a domain based network and a non-domain based network at the same time.
182.solution: Make sure 'Prohibit connection to non-domain networks when connected to domain authenticated network' is set to 'Enabled'

183.description: 18.4.22.2.1 Set 'Allow Windows to auto connect to open hotspots, networks shared by contacts, and hotspots with paid services' to 'Disabled'
183.info: This policy setting determines whether users can enable the following WLAN settings: 'Connect to suggested open hotspots', 'Connect to networks shared by my contacts', and 'Enable paid services'.
183.solution: Make sure 'Allow Windows to auto connect to open hotspots, networks shared by contacts, and hotspots with paid services' is set to 'Disabled'

184.description: 18.6.1 Set 'Apply UAC restrictions to local accounts on network logons' to 'Enabled'
184.info: This setting controls whether local accounts can be used for remote administration via network logon such as NET USE, connecting to C$.
184.solution: Make sure 'Apply UAC restrictions to local accounts on network logons' is set to 'Enabled'.

185.info: When WDigest authentication is enabled, Lsass.exe retains a copy of the user's plaintext password in memory, where it can be at risk of theft. If this setting is not configured.
185.solution: Make sure 'WDigest Authentication' is set to 'Disabled'.

186.description: 18.8.2.1 Set 'Include command line in process creation events' to 'Disabled'
186.info: This policy setting determines what information is logged in security audit events when a new process has been created.
186.solution: Make sure 'Include command line in process creation events' is set to 'Disabled'

187.description: 18.8.11.1 Set 'Boot-Start Driver Initialization Policy' to 'Enabled:Good, unknown and bad but critical'
187.info: This policy setting allows you to specify which boot-start drivers are initialized based on a classification determined by an Early Launch Antimalware boot-start driver.
187.solution: Make sure 'Boot-Start Driver Initialization Policy' is set to 'Enabled:Good, unknown and bad but critical'

188.description: 18.8.18.2 Set 'Configure registry policy processing: Do not apply during periodic background processing' to 'Enabled: FALSE'
188.info: The 'Do not apply during periodic background processing' option prevents the system from updating affected policies in the background while the computer is in use.
188.solution: Make sure 'Configure registry policy processing: Do not apply during periodic background processing' is set to 'Enabled: FALSE'

189.description: 18.8.18.3 Set 'Configure registry policy processing: Process even if the Group Policy objects have not changed' to 'Enabled: TRUE'
189.info: The 'Process even if the Group Policy objects have not changed' option updates and reapplies policies even if the policies have not changed.
189.solution: Make sure 'Configure registry policy processing: Process even if the Group Policy objects have not changed' is set to 'Enabled: TRUE'

190.description: 18.8.18.4 Set 'Turn off background refresh of Group Policy' to 'Disabled'
190.info: This policy setting prevents Group Policy from being updated while the computer is in use. This policy setting applies to Group Policy for computers, users and domain controllers.
190.solution: Make sure 'Turn off background refresh of Group Policy' is set to 'Disabled'

191.description: 18.8.24.1 Set 'Do not display network selection UI' to 'Enabled'
191.info: This policy setting allows you to control whether anyone can interact with available networks UI on the logon screen.
191.solution: Make sure 'Do not display network selection UI' is set to 'Enabled'

192.description: 18.8.24.2 Set 'Do not enumerate connected users on domain-joined computers' to 'Enabled'
192.info: This policy setting prevents connected users from being enumerated on domain-joined computers.
192.solution: Make sure 'Do not enumerate connected users on domain-joined computers' is set to 'Enabled'

193.description: 18.8.24.3 Set 'Enumerate local users on domain-joined computers' to 'Disabled'
193.info: This policy setting allows local users to be enumerated on domain-joined computers.
193.solution: Make sure 'Enumerate local users on domain-joined computers' is set to 'Disabled'

194.description: 18.8.24.4 Set 'Turn off app notifications on the lock screen' to 'Enabled'
194.info: This policy setting allows you to prevent app notifications from appearing on the lock screen.
194.solution: Make sure 'Turn off app notifications on the lock screen' is set to 'Enabled'

195.info: This policy setting allows you to control whether a domain user can sign in using a PIN.
195.solution: Make sure 'Turn on PIN sign-in' is set to 'Disabled'

196.description: 18.8.25.1 Set 'Untrusted Font Blocking' to 'Enabled: Block untrusted fonts and log events'
196.info: This security feature provides a global setting to prevent programs from loading untrusted fonts. Untrusted fonts are any font installed outside of the %windir%\Fonts directory. This feature can be configured to be in 3 modes: On, Off, and Audit.
196.solution: Make sure 'Untrusted Font Blocking' to 'Enabled: Block untrusted fonts and log events'

197.description: 18.8.28.4.3 Set 'Require a Password When a Computer Wakes (On Battery)' to 'Enabled'
197.info: This control determines if Windows requires a password after it resumes from sleep.
197.solution: Make sure 'Require a Password When a Computer Wakes (On Battery)' is Enabled.

198.description: 18.8.28.4.4 Set 'Require a Password When a Computer Wakes (Plugged In)' to 'Enabled'
198.info: This control determines if Windows requires a password after it resumes from sleep.
198.solution: Make sure 'Require a Password When a Computer Wakes (Plugged In)' is Enabled.

199.info: This policy setting allows you to turn on or turn off Offer (Unsolicited) Remote Assistance on this computer.
199.solution: Make sure Set 'Configure Offer Remote Assistance' is Disabled

200.info: This policy setting allows you to turn on or turn off Solicited (Ask for) Remote Assistance on this computer.
200.solution: Make sure Set 'Configure Solicited Remote Assistance' is Disabled

201.description: 18.8.31.1 Set 'Enable RPC Endpoint Mapper Client Authentication' to 'Enabled'
201.info: This policy setting controls whether RPC clients authenticate with the Endpoint Mapper Service when the call

203.description: 18.9.6.1 Set 'Allow Microsoft accounts to be optional' to 'Enabled'

204.description: 18.9.8.1 Set 'Disallow Autoplay for non-volume devices' to 'Enabled'
204.info: This policy setting disallows AutoPlay for MTP devices like cameras or phones.

205.description: 18.9.8.2 Set 'Set the default behavior for AutoRun' to 'Enabled: Do not execute any autorun commands'
205.info: This policy setting sets the default behavior for Autorun commands. Autorun commands are generally stored in autorun.inf files.
205.solution: Make sure 'Set the default behavior for AutoRun' is set to 'Enabled: Do not execute any autorun commands'

206.description: 18.9.8.3 Set 'Turn off Autoplay on' to 'Enabled:All drives'
206.info: Enable the Turn off Autoplay setting to disable the Autoplay feature.

207.description: 18.9.13.1 Set 'Do not display the password reveal button' to 'Enabled'

208.description: 18.9.13.2 Set 'Enumerate administrator accounts on elevation' to 'Disabled'
208.info: This control defines whether a user is allowed to see all administrator accounts displayed when a user attempts to elevate a running application.

209.info: This policy setting determines the amount of diagnostic and usage data reported to Microsoft.

210.description: 18.9.14.2 Set 'Disable pre-release features or settings' to 'Disabled'
210.info: This policy setting determines the level that Microsoft can experiment with the product to study user preferences or device behavior.

211.description: 18.9.14.3 Set 'Toggle user control over Insider builds' to 'Disabled'
211.info: This policy setting determines whether users can access the Insider build controls in the Advanced Options for Windows Update.
211.solution: Make sure 'Toggle user control over Insider builds' is set to 'Disabled'

212.info: Set this policy to configure the use of Windows Update Delivery Optimization in downloads of Windows Apps and Updates.

213.description: 18.9.24.1.1 Set 'Application: Control Event Log behavior when the log file reaches its maximum size' to 'Disabled'

214.description: 18.9.24.1.2 Set 'Application: Maximum Log Size (KB)' to 'Enabled:32,768 or greater'

215.description: 18.9.24.2.1 Set 'Security: Control Event Log behavior when the log file reaches its maximum size' to 'Disabled'
215.info: This policy setting controls Event Log behavior when the log file reaches its maximum size.

216.description: 18.9.24.2.2 Set 'Security: Maximum Log Size (KB)' to 'Enabled:196,608 or greater'
216.info: This policy setting specifies the maximum size of the log file in kilobytes.

217.info: This policy setting controls Event Log behavior when the log file reaches its maximum size.

218.description: 18.9.24.3.2 Set 'Setup: Maximum Log Size (KB)' to 'Enabled:32,768 or greater'
218.info: This policy setting specifies the maximum size of the log file in kilobytes.

219.description: 18.9.24.4.1 Set 'System: Control Event Log behavior when the log file reaches its maximum size' to 'Disabled'
219.info: This policy setting controls Event Log behavior when the log file reaches its maximum size.
219.solution: Make sure 'System: Control Event Log behavior when the log file reaches its maximum size' is set to 'Disabled'

220.description: 18.9.24.4.2 Set 'System: Maximum Log Size (KB)' to 'Enabled:32,768 or greater'
220.info: This policy setting controls Event Log behavior when the log file reaches its maximum size.

222.description: 18.9.28.3 Set 'Turn off Data Execution Prevention for Explorer' to 'Disabled'

224.description: 18.9.28.5 Set 'Turn off shell protocol protected mode' to 'Disabled'

225.description: 18.9.31.1 Set 'Prevent the computer from joining a homegroup' to 'Enabled'

226.description: 18.9.43.1 Set 'Prevent the usage of OneDrive for file storage' to 'Enabled'

227.description: 18.9.48.2.2 Set 'Do not allow passwords to be saved' to 'Enabled'

228.description: 18.9.48.3.3.2 Set 'Do not allow drive redirection' to 'Enabled'
228.info: This control defines whether a user is allowed to share the local drives on their client computers to Terminal Servers that they access.

229.description: 18.9.48.3.9.1 Set 'Always prompt for password upon connection' to 'Enabled'
229.info: This policy setting specifies whether Terminal Services always prompts the client computer for a password upon connection.

231.description: 18.9.48.3.9.3 Set 'Set client connection encryption level:Encryption Level' to 'Enabled:High Level'

231.solution: Set 'Set client connection encryption level:Encryption Level' to 'Enabled:High Level'

232.description: 18.9.48.3.11.1 Set 'Do not use temporary folders per session' to 'Disabled'
232.info: By default, Remote Desktop Services creates a separate temporary folder on the RD Session Host server for each active session that a user maintains on the RD Session Host server.

233.info: This policy setting specifies whether Cortana is allowed on the device.

236.description: 18.9.67.1 Set 'Enables or disables Windows Game Recording and Broadcasting' to 'Disabled'

237.description: 18.9.68.1 Set 'Allow user control over installs' to 'Disabled'

238.description: 18.9.68.2 Set 'Always install with elevated privileges' to 'Disabled'

239.description: 18.9.69.1 Set 'Sign-in last interactive user automatically after a system-initiated restart' to 'Disabled'

242.info: This policy setting allows you to manage whether the Windows Remote Management (WinRM) client uses Basic authentication.

243.info: This policy setting allows you to manage whether the Windows Remote Management (WinRM) service sends and receives unencrypted messages over the network.

244.info: This policy setting allows you to manage whether the Windows Remote Management (WinRM) client will not use Digest authentication.

245.info: This policy setting allows you to manage whether the Windows Remote Management (WinRM) client uses Basic authentication.

246.info: This policy setting allows you to manage whether the Windows Remote Management (WinRM) service sends and receives unencrypted messages over the network.

248.info: This policy setting specifies whether computers in your environment will receive security updates from Windows Update or WSUS.

249.description: 18.9.84.2 Set 'Configure Automatic Updates: Scheduled install day' to '0 - Every day'
249.info: This policy setting specifies whether computers in your environment will receive security updates from Windows Update or WSUS.
249.solution: Make sure 'Configure Automatic Updates: Scheduled install day' to '0 - Every day'

250.info: If you enable this policy setting, in Pro and Enterprise SKUs you can defer upgrades till the next upgrade period (at least a few months).

251.description: 18.9.84.4 Set 'No auto-restart with logged on users for scheduled automatic updates installations' to 'Disabled'
251.info: This policy setting specifies that Automatic Updates will wait for computers to be restarted by the users who are logged on to them to complete a scheduled installation.

252.info: This policy setting allows you to manage whether or not screen savers run.

254.description: 19.1.3.3 Set 'Password protect the screen saver' to 'Enabled'

255.description: 19.1.3.4 Set 'Screen saver timeout' to 'Enabled:900 or fewer seconds, but not 0'

260.description: 19.7.37.1 Set 'Always install with elevated privileges' to 'Disabled'
